text_english: Coordination and distribution of the governance structure for IS4H accountability and decision-making at the managerial and technical level among all actors.

maturity_1: Accountability and decision-making for IS4H components is distributed across different units within institutional authorities, and investments and activities are not coordinated.
maturity_2: IS4H investment decisions are coordinated at the management level within individual authorities but not formally coordinated among other institutional entities.
maturity_3: There is a formal governance structure in place for strategic planning and oversight of IS4H among the institutional entities
maturity_4: IS4H governance structures are established at the institutional level across at least some key national stakeholders (e.g. health authorities, national IT authorities, vital Statistics, national statistics authorities)
maturity_5: The governance and management of IS4H is fully transparent and integrated across all national stakeholder institutions.

question_text: Roles and functions of key institutional actors are formally documented and mapped.
maturity_1: No mapping or documentation exist. Knowledge of roles and functions of information system actors resides in individuals.
maturity_2: Individual entities have mapped the roles and functions of some key roles but not shared at the institutional level.
maturity_3: There is a formal roster of instititutional information system actors documented and available.
maturity_4: There is a formal roster of institutional information system actors with a mapping of roles and relationships.
maturity_5: Health information system functions, roles and responsibilities are mapped, integrated and aligned across institution.

question_text: Decisions mechanisms for IS4H strategic priorities, investments and technical approaches.
maturity_1: Decision for IS4H are only addressed at the unit level
maturity_2: There is no formal governance structure within the institution, but IS4H issues are routinely discussed within the Institution's executive leadership body.
maturity_3: There is a formal IS4H governance structure within the institution in adoption.
maturity_4: There is an institutional governance structure with key institutional managerial stakeholders implemented in most entities.
maturity_5: The institutional governance structure is fully integrated with the IS4H governance structure in entire the institution.

text_english: Addressing IS4H under policies, strategies and SOPs at the institutional level. Mechanisms for developing or adopting an IS4H governance strategy or policy that promotes a better decision- and informed policy-making mechanisms.

maturity_1: There is no current Institutional Strategic IS4H Plan and IS4H components are not reflected in operational plans.
maturity_2: There is a institutional Strategic IS4H Plan, but it does not address IS4H. Some individual teams/units/departments include some components of IS4H in their operational plans.
maturity_3: There is a current institutional Strategic IS4H Plan that includes priorities for strengthening health information. IS4H is included within operational plans of institution
maturity_4: There is a formal strategic plan in place among institutional authorities for strengthening IS4H that reflects the IS4H Strategic Framework. Operational plans of the units/departments within institution reflect IS4H activities and outcomes based on the IS4H Strategic Plan.
maturity_5: There is an institutional Strategic IS4H Plan, and operational plans are aligned and integrated across multisectoral stakeholders.

question_text: There is an institutional IS4H Strategic Plan.
maturity_1: There is no current Institutional Strategic IS4H Plan.
maturity_2: There is a current Institutional Strategic IS4H Plan, but it does not address components of IS4H.
maturity_3: There is a current Institutional Strategic IS4H Plan that includes a priority for strengthening health information that reflects two or more strategic domains within the IS4H framework.
maturity_4: There is a formal strategic plan in place among institutional authorities for strengthening IS4H that reflects all of the domains in the IS4H Strategic Framework
maturity_5: There is a comprehensive Institutional Strategic IS4H Plan that includes strategic goals and initiatives from multi-sectoral partners.

question_text: There is an institutional IS4H operational plan.
maturity_1: IS4H components are not reflected in operational plans.
maturity_2: Some teams/units/departments are are developing their operational plans to include IS4H components.
maturity_3: IS4H is specifically included within the operational plan of some teams/units/departments
maturity_4: IS4H is specifically included within the operational plan of most teams/units/departments
maturity_5: IS4H operational is fully aligned with Institutional IS4H Strategic Plan of the Institution.

text_english: institutional structure & information flows of health-related institutions, roles and responsibilities of IS4H actors.

maturity_1: Some IS4H functions are formally defined and performed, but there are significant gaps
maturity_2: There are gaps in IS4H services or functions, and/or services and functions may be duplicated across teams/units/departments.
maturity_3: Accountability and responsibility for IS4H functions within institution have been defined, and there are plans in place for institutional restructuring or re-alignment to rationalize functions and decision-making.
maturity_4: An institutional structure that defines clear accountabilities and responsibilities for IS4H has been fully implemented within institution, and is reflected in unit/program mandates and job descriptions.
maturity_5: IS4H functions are defined, performed and aligned across stakeholders. Functions are integrated across stakeholders, optimizing performance, value and investments at the institutional level.

question_text: There is a documented and formally adopted structure (organigram) for the institution.
maturity_1: No formal institutional structure is defined.
maturity_2: Yes, but the institutional structure has not yet been formally approved or published.
maturity_3: Yes, but IS4H roles and responsibilities are not fully reflected.
maturity_4: Yes, with IS4H roles and responsibilities fully reflected.
maturity_5: Yes, with IS4H fully reflected and aligned with institutional structures across multisectoral partners.

question_text: The overall leadership and accountability for IS4H is defined.
maturity_1: IS4H responsibility is not currently defined and there is no clear leadership for IS4H.
maturity_2: Responsibility for IS4H is defined within institution for teams/units/departments, but there is no clear leadership for IS4H.
maturity_3: Leadership for IS4H is defined, and there are formal plans for institutional re-structuring to clearly define roles and responsibilities within the institution.
maturity_4: Responsibility for IS4H is defined and integrated in the institution, and leadership is well defined.
maturity_5: Leadership and accountabilities for IS4H are well defined across multi-sectoral national partners.

question_text: Change management program is integrated into the institutional culture-capacity.
maturity_1: There is no awareness of the importance of change management at the leadership level.
maturity_2: There is awareness of principles, but no institutional capacity to implement change management methodologies
maturity_3: Some capacity for change management but lack institutional resources
maturity_4: There is a formal and efficient change management program unit or team.
maturity_5: Change management is an integral part of initiatives and projects

question_text: There are formally defined institutional functions for:

maturity_1: Some IS4H functions formally present and performed with significant gaps.
maturity_2: Most functions are performed but not formally defined, and/or there are overlapping accountabilities or duplication of efforts.
maturity_3: Functions are defined, and there are plans to address gaps and to align accountabilities.
maturity_4: Functions are fully defined and accountabilities are aligned within the institution
maturity_5: Functions are fully defined and accountabilities are aligned across multisectoral partners

maturity_1: Some IS4H functions formally present and performed with significant gaps.
maturity_2: Most functions are performed but not formally defined, and/or there are overlapping accountabilities or duplication of efforts.
maturity_3: Functions are defined, and there are plans to address gaps and to align accountabilities.
maturity_4: Functions are fully defined and accountabilities are aligned within the institution
maturity_5: Functions are fully defined and accountabilities are aligned across multisectoral partners

maturity_1: Some IS4H functions formally present and performed with significant gaps.
maturity_2: Most functions are performed but not formally defined, and/or there are overlapping accountabilities or duplication of efforts.
maturity_3: Functions are defined, and there are plans to address gaps and to align accountabilities.
maturity_4: Functions are fully defined and accountabilities are aligned within the institution
maturity_5: Functions are fully defined and accountabilities are aligned across multisectoral partners

maturity_1: Some IS4H functions formally present and performed with significant gaps.
maturity_2: Most functions are performed but not formally defined, and/or there are overlapping accountabilities or duplication of efforts.
maturity_3: Functions are defined, and there are plans to address gaps and to align accountabilities.
maturity_4: Functions are fully defined and accountabilities are aligned within the institution
maturity_5: Functions are fully defined and accountabilities are aligned across multisectoral partners

question_text: There are policies and standard operating procedures defined to guide activities and processes within the IS4H core functions:

maturity_1: There are few, if any, policies/SOPs defined to guide the activities and processes across IS4H domains.
maturity_2: There are some policies/SOPs defined to guide IS4H activities and processes, but many are out of date, or not formally adopted within the institution
maturity_3: Specific gaps in policies/SOPs have been identified, and there are plans in progress to update and adopt policies/SOPs within the institution
maturity_4: Policies/SOPs are well defined and formally adopted to guide IS4H activities and processes within the institution
maturity_5: Policies/SOPs are to guide IS4H activities and processes, and are integrated and aligned across multisectoral stakeholders.

maturity_1: There are few, if any, policies/SOPs defined to guide the activities and processes across IS4H domains.
maturity_2: There are some policies/SOPs defined to guide IS4H activities and processes, but many are out of date, or not formally adopted within the institution
maturity_3: Specific gaps in policies/SOPs have been identified, and there are plans in progress to update and adopt policies/SOPs within the institution
maturity_4: Policies/SOPs are well defined and formally adopted to guide IS4H activities and processes within the institution
maturity_5: Policies/SOPs are to guide IS4H activities and processes, and are integrated and aligned across multi-sectoral stakeholders.

maturity_1: There are few, if any, policies/SOPs defined to guide the activities and processes across IS4H domains.
maturity_2: There are some policies/SOPs defined to guide IS4H activities and processes, but many are out of date, or not formally adopted within institution
maturity_3: Specific gaps in policies/SOPs have been identified, and there are plans in progress to update and adopt policies/SOPs within institution
maturity_4: Policies/SOPs are well defined and formally adopted to guide IS4H activities and processes within the institution
maturity_5: Policies/SOPs are to guide IS4H activities and processes, and are integrated and aligned across multi-sectoral stakeholders.

maturity_2: There are some policies/SOPs defined to guide IS4H activities and processes, but many are out of date, or not formally adopted within institution
maturity_3: Specific gaps in policies/SOPs have been identified, and there are plans in progress to update and adopt policies/SOPs within institution
maturity_4: Policies/SOPs are well defined and formally adopted to guide IS4H activities and processes within the institution
maturity_5: Policies/SOPs are to guide IS4H activities and processes, and are integrated and aligned across multi-sectoral stakeholders.

text_english: Budget for IS4H implementation, sustainability, investment. Resources mobilization plans and ERP systems.

maturity_1: IS4H activities/resources are not formally identified in unit/department budgets. While it is sometimes possible to secure one-time financial resources for IS4H investments, required investments are difficult to sustain.
maturity_2: IS4H activities are identified in unit/department annual budgets of institution, but are not integrated or aligned across units/departments. The financial resources requirements to effectively sustain IS4H have been identified, but there is no plan to address gaps.
maturity_3: There is a plan in place for resource mobilization for specific IS4H capital investments. Financial resources secured for the sustainable implementation. Operations of IS4H have been secured with annual budgets.
maturity_4: An IS4H investment framework is established at the institutional level.
maturity_5: IS4H is fully sustainable, supported by an investment model that ensures the required human resources, processes, legal-ethical framework, knowledge and technologies are available to deliver ISH effectively, and to continually invest in new capabilities as they emerge.

question_text: Financial requirements and resources for IS4H are available.
maturity_1: Financial requirements for IS4H are not known, although it is sometime possible to secure one-time, limited financial resources.
maturity_2: Financial resource requirements for some components of IS4H are known, but there is no plan in place to address financial resource gaps.
maturity_3: Financial requirements for IS4H are known. Although the required financial resources are not fully available, there is a resource mobilization strategy in place.
maturity_4: There is an IS4H investment framework at the institutional level that identifies financial resource requirements and investment sources.
maturity_5: IS4H is sustainable supported by an investment model that address both short-term operational finance resource requirements, and longer-term innovation and capacity development.

question_text: There are formal budgets for planning, implementing and sustaining IS4H.
maturity_1: Budgets do not specifically include line-items for IS4H components.
maturity_2: Budgets do no include specific line-items for IS4H components, but budgets do include IS4H components under other line-items (e.g. program budgets).
maturity_3: Units/departments have line-items for some IS4H components in their budgets, but it is not possible to roll-up these budgets at the institutional level.
maturity_4: There are specific budget line-items for IS4H components that are consistent across units/departments and that can be rolled up across the institution
maturity_5: There are specific budget line-items for IS4H components that are consistent across multi-sectoral stakeholders that can be rolled up at the institutional level.

text_english: Human capital for planning, implementing, and managing IS4H. Competency building activities to strengthen to IS4H skills. Job functions identified to effectively support IS4H.

maturity_1: There is little awareness of the human resource requirements to support IS4H.
maturity_2: There are identified human resource constraints for planning, implementing, and managing IS4H, but there is no formal plan for addressing human resource needs.
maturity_3: Skills and job functions required to effectively support IS4H have been identified, although not all resources have yet been secured. There are is some evidence of competency building activities (training, workshops, conferences) for IS4H domains but these are typically ad hoc.
maturity_4: Sufficient human resources with the required skills to effectively implement and sustain IS4H have been secured. Relevant IS4H skills and competency development are integrated into training plans for leadership, management and staff.
maturity_5: There is a institutional strategy for building IS4H human resource competencies that includes international educational institutions to ensure the long term availability of skilled IS4H resources.

question_text: There are identified human resource requirements for:

maturity_1: No IS4H human resource requirements have been identified.
maturity_2: Human resource requirements have been identified, but there are no formal plans to address gaps
maturity_3: There are short-term plans in place to address human resource gaps.
maturity_4: There is a long-term IS4H human resources strategy in place that reflects the overall IS4H strategic priorities.
maturity_5: There is a institutional IS4H human resource strategy in place aligned with multisectoral partners.

question_text: Human resources with the required knowledge and skills to effectively implement and sustain IS4H are available:

maturity_1: There are few IS4H human resources available.
maturity_2: There are some IS4H human resources available, but not sufficient to effectively plan and implement IS4H.
maturity_3: There are IS4H human resources available, but recruitment and retention of skilled resources is an ongoing challenge.
maturity_4: There is enough human resource capacity to effectively sustain IS4H.
maturity_5: There is enough human resource capacity to drive continuous innovation across all the core IS4H domains.

text_english: Relations with public and private key stakeholders at institutional and interinstitutional level.

maturity_1: Identified key stakeholders are from the public health sector exclusively.
maturity_2: There are some relationships with other public sector stakeholder for specific some information and service needs. However, engagement and coordination is ad hoc.
maturity_3: Informal relationships have been established with key multisectoral national actors, including private sector institutions.
maturity_4: Formal relationships have been established with multisectoral actors, including the private sector. There are examples are collaborative initiatives between multisector partners.
maturity_5: IS4H governance includes representation from multi-sectoral partners. IS4H roles, responsibilities and functions are aligned across multisectoral partners.

question_text: There are established relationships with other public sector stakeholders for information sharing and coordination.

maturity_1: No relationships
maturity_2: Information sharing with other health system stakeholders is ad hoc, for some specific information needs.
maturity_3: Information sharing with public sector stakeholders happens routinely, but not based on a formal agreement.
maturity_4: There are specific formal intersectoral agreements for information sharing.
maturity_5: Institutional IS4H governance structure provides formal arrangements for the sharing of information across multisectoral partners.

text_english: Key and core legislation, policy and compliance mechanisms, elements to enable IS4H implementation, operation and maintenance.

maturity_1: There is some awareness that there are gaps in legislation, policy and compliance mechanisms that create barriers to the effective use of IS4H, but specific gaps and needs have not been formally documented.
maturity_2: Requirements for IS4H enabling legislation, policy and compliance mechanism have been identified, but solutions have not yet implemented.
maturity_3: There are policies and SOPs that address ethical use and protection of health data (e.g., privacy, security, secondary use), but there may be gaps in regulation or legislation.
maturity_4: The legislation, policies, and compliance mechanism required to effectively implement and operate IS4H are implemented.
maturity_5: The legal-ethical framework fully enables the use of information and technology to improve health outcomes and the performance of the health system while protecting individuals and populations, and is responsive to emerging innovations.

maturity_4: Yes, up to date, implemented and routinely maintained.
maturity_5: Yes, and mechanism are able to accommodate emergent requirements driven by innovations or new strategic priorities.

question_text: There is a policy for the ethical collection and secondary use of data that recognizes the inherent biases in data and analyses.
maturity_1: No
maturity_2: Some guidelines exist, but there is no formal policy.
maturity_3: Some teams/units/departments have polices as part of their institutional policy framework.
maturity_4: There are policies at the institutional level for the public health sector.
maturity_5: There are policies at the institutional level that apply to all multisectoral stakeholders.

question_text: There is legislation/regulation enabling the effective use of electronic medical records.
maturity_1: No
maturity_2: Some guidelines exist, but there is no formal policy, regulation or legislation.
maturity_3: There are formal policies in place governing the effective use of electronic medical records.
maturity_4: There is legislation that enables the effective use of electronic medical records.
maturity_5: There is legislation that enables the effective use of a national electronic health record.

question_text: There is legislation/regulation addressing the protection of personal health information (health information privacy).
maturity_1: No
maturity_2: There is general legislation that addresses the protection of data, but it does not specifically address electronic health information.
maturity_3: There are regulatory/policy mechanisms that addresses the protection of health information, within a general data protection legal framework.
maturity_4: There is a legislation that specifically address the protection of personal health information in the context of electronic health information.
maturity_5: The legal and regulatory framework is flexible and able to accommodate emergent requirements for the protection of personal health information.

text_english: National and International agreements to contextualize strategic planning and investments. Commitment to regional and global mandates.

maturity_1: There is some awareness of data and reporting obligations under interinstitutional and international agreements, but little capacity to meet obligations.
maturity_2: Data and reporting obligations under interinstitutional and international agreements are frequently met, but with high resource impact.
maturity_3: Data and reporting obligations under interinstitutional and international agreements are consistently met with an effective use of resources.
maturity_4: Agreements enable data and information sharing across interinstitutional and international stakeholders.
maturity_5: Data and information are able to flow freely among interinstitutional and international partners in support of agreements, guided by frameworks that ensure the ethical use of information that protects individuals and populations.
